data.title: Documentation about compiling for Android for 2.1.1-stable needs 2 additions.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Xubuntu 16.04 64-bit , Godot 2.1.1-stable but probably also 2.1-stable

**Problem 1**

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After doing all steps from documentation 
http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/reference/compiling_for_x11.html#distro-specific-oneliners 
and taking care of all needed requirements from 
http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/reference/compiling_for_android.html
Compilation stops at error:

```
Incremental java compilation is an incubating feature.
:preBuild UP-TO-DATE
:preDebugBuild UP-TO-DATE
:checkDebugManifest
:preReleaseBuild UP-TO-DATE
:prepareComAndroidSupportSupportV42340Library UP-TO-DATE
:prepareDebugDependencies
:compileDebugAidl FAILED

FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.

* What went wrong:
Execution failed for task ':compileDebugAidl'.
> java.lang.RuntimeException: org.gradle.process.internal.ExecException: A problem occurred starting process 'command '/home/user1/Android/android-sdk-linux/build-tools/23.0.3/aidl''

* Try:
Run with --stacktrace option to get the stack trace. Run with --info or --debug option to get more log output.

BUILD FAILED
```

Only after installing additional and not mentioned in the documentation 32-bit libraries it's possible to build Android templates.

Please add `lib32z1 lib32ncurses5 lib32stdc++6` to the required one liner on Ubuntu.
For Fedora it probably should be `zlib.i686 ncurses-libs.i686 bzip2-libs.i686`
in the documentation at http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/reference/compiling_for_x11.html#distro-specific-oneliners
or maybe at the http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/reference/compiling_for_android.html .


**Problem 2**

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
In the r10e version of Android NDK, in the /toolchains/ folder there is no /llvm/ subfolder that Scons is looking for, so Scons fails to compile for Android.
There are only llvm-3.5 and llvm-3.6 folders, so simple solution is to create a llvm symlink to llvm-3.6 or change Scons to search in more places for llvm* folder.

data.title: AudioServerSW::update() : is this a bug ?
Proposal: Adding cartesian to polar conversion functions
data.body:
*Bugsquad edit:* Repurposing this issue based on https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/7285#issuecomment-272994312

@tagcup wrote:
> Conversion between degrees and a general 2D vector doesn't make any sense to me, in mathematical terms: the norm of a 2D vector isn't necessarily equal to 1. You can't convert between two degrees of freedom (Vector2) and one degree of freedom (an angle) in a meaningful way.
> 
> I would rather propose adding functions that converts between polar and cartesian coordinates in 2D: (x,y) <-> (r,θ) where θ is in radians. The API could be something like cartesian_to_polar(x,y) and polar_to_cartesian(r,θ), each returning a vector.
> 
> Or alternatively, simply a polar constructor for Vector2.

--------------

*Original proposal:*

I find that a lot of users (me included) have the need to convert angles (in radian or degrees) into a Vector2 direction.

The current way to get a Vector2 direction from an angle;
```
  var radian_value = PI # 180 degrees
  var my_vec2 = **Vector2(cos(radian_value), sin(radian_value))**
```

I propose that we add new functions such as **rad2vec**(rad_value) and **deg2vec**(deg_value) with the other functions found at the [core](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/classes/class_@gdscript.html).

This will make the process much cleaner for everyone, and we wont have to know/remember this formula. :)

data.title: Click on the debug option closes the menu
data.body: **Operating system or device - Godot version:** Mac OS X 10.11.4 (MBP 2015 Retina) - Godot v2.1.1.stable **Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected): Each click on the debug option to select/deselect it, closes the menu. So, in order to select four debug options I have to reopen the "Debug options" menu four times. **Steps to reproduce:** 1. Open the "Debug options" menu. 2. Click on any of the options to select/deselect it. 3. Menu will close.

data.title: Font import doesn't allow dynamic fonts
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Mac OS X 10.11.4 (MBP 2015 Retina) - Godot v2.1.1.stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

When I drag and drop a .ttf font file onto Editor's "FileSystem" pane, the window titled "Font Import" shows up.
The only import modes it has are Bitmap and Distance Field.
But I just want to add .ttf font file to the resources, to use it as a newly supported dynamic font.
I managed to add the .ttf font file to the resources using Finder, but it would be easier to just drag and drop onto Editor.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Drag and drop .ttf font file from Finder to Editor's FileSystem pane.

data.title: HiDPI Mode issue with multiple monitors
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Mac OS X 10.11.4 (MBP 2015 Retina) - Godot v2.1.1.stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I would like to move the Editor to my external 27" display (2560x1440).
When I click the Godot's dock icon, the Project Manager is launched first.
Then, no matter which display is Project Manager on, after launching the project, Editor will always open on my internal MBP's display.
Editor looks good on retina with HiDPI Mode set to both Auto and HiDPI.
But when I move the Editor's window to external display, it becomes unusable:

![doubled_editor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5592468/20948945/01c54074-bc17-11e6-8a23-2d0ab2ccadc4.png)

If I move the Editor's window back to retina it becomes fine again.
Setting HiDPI Mode to LoDPI doesn't fix the issue, everything just looks super tiny on retina and still broken on LoDPI display.
Is there a way to launch Editor directly on external display?
I expected the "Auto" mode to handle displays automatically.
 
**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Launch Godot project via Godot Project Manager.
2. Move the Editor from HiDPI display (for example retina) to any other LoDPI display.
3. Editor will become scaled and unusable.

They become sharp again after closing apps. It happens on both HiDPI and LoDPI displays. **Steps to reproduce:** 1. Click Godot Project Manager icon in the dock. 2. Icon will become blurry. 3. Close the Godot Project Manager. 4. Icon will become sharp again. The same steps work for Godot Editor dock icon.

data.title: Collision mask checking for 3D physics
data.body:
This should hopefully fix issue #7227 

The collision mask info was in there, but it wasn't being used in the actual collision code, so I've added it. Not sure if it needs to be added elsewhere? Not too familiar with the physics code, but KinematicBody (3d) now appears to behave correctly when using layers/masks.

If anyone else could test, that would be great.

data.title: bug with collisions shapes in saved scenes
data.body:
- create saved scene with staticbody2d as root
- add it to game scene
- add collisionshape to it
- rigidbody2d will fall through it

it will only work if collisionshape not only added inside savedscene, but also configured (shape created) in its hyerarchy and not in game scene hyerarchy.

and if you move such (with enabled editable children) collisionshape (part of saved scene) somewhere down (for example putting it after an added sprite node (inside game scene i mean)), there would appear two collisionshapes, one read and one white, but you couldn't delete ant of them anymore.

i was trying to create a general staticbody2d with script, that would represent different types of platforms, depending on settings i setup in exported script options. the only things i planned to edit manually - adding sprite nodes and collisionshape (one) as children of that instanced saved scene, but now it is impossible to implement.

godot 2.2 latest.

data.title: WebM: Compilation fail on Linux/ARM
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux ARM

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Cannot link on Arch Linux ARM (missing `vpx_ports/arm_cpudetect.c` in compilation source files):
```
modules/libmodules.x11.opt.tools.32.a(systemdependent.x11.opt.tools.32.o): In function `vp8_machine_specific_config':
thirdparty/libvpx/vp8/common/generic/systemdependent.c:(.text+0x28): undefined reference to `arm_cpu_caps'
```
Also ARM assembly code is not used for Linux/ARM architecture.

data.title: Godot froze by inflating the editor_settings.tres file to 385MB with 82 C2 and 82 C3 pairs of bytes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux
Godot 2.2.r6004.4235abe (godot-git)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
While working on a project, I added a Sprite and realized I have the filter on. I went to Project Settings, Image Loader, unchecked the box on the left of `filter` and suddenly Godot froze. I forcefully closed it by killing it's parent process (the desktop environment).

From that point on, every single attempt to start Godot ended in it being stuck on the logo screen with 100% CPU and ever-increasing memory usage.

Through the use of `strace` I have located the source of this bug to be the `editor_settings.tres` file, and immediately realized I was not wrong - the file weighed 385 MB. Through the use of `head` and `tail` commands I have managed to locate the position of the problem - the file was filled with pairs of bytes 82 C2 and 82 C3. However, this wasn't the whole file - the beginning was intact.

Further inspection revealed that the corruption started at the character that was supposed to be `ż` in the name of a different project (not the one I was working on before Godot froze for the first time) - represented as C5 BC in Unicode.

**Steps to reproduce:**
I have not yet found any way to reproduce this.
I have tried reimporting the two projects with a fresh `.godot`, and deselecting `filter` - which worked.

**Link to `editor_settings.tres`:**
https://zatherz.eu/junk/editor_settings.zip
Note: the zip is 3.6 MB, but 385MB after unpacking.

data.title: Popups/windowdialogs steal focus from sub-controls which pop up over them
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux Mint 18 x64, Godot 2.1.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
In the example project, an OptionButton is placed in a PopupPanel. Below it are several other UI controls. The PopupPanel is displayed with show() and is exclusive. (The bug also occurs with popup() and non-exclusive popups.) When the OptionButton is clicked, it displays its item list. Clicks on the item list above the PopupPanel's other UI controls are delivered to those controls instead of the OptionButton's item list. Expected behavior is that the OptionButton's item list will receive the clicks, since it is the top item.

This issue appears to be a general issue with any stacked popup. In a more complicated project, I have a windowdialog which displays above another windowdialog. Clicks to the top windowdialog are delivered preferentially to any clickable UI control in the bottom windowdialog, rather than to the top windowdialog as would be expected.

**Steps to reproduce:**
 1. Create a popup of some kind.
 2. To the first popup, add another popup.
 3. To the first popup, add some additional UI controls.
 4. Display the first popup, then display the second popup.
 5. Observe that clicks on the second popup, when they occur above the first popup's controls, are delivered to the first popup's controls instead of the second popup.

**Demo project:**
This project contains a minimal demo of the issue. Click the OptionButton and notice that clicking on the first few items is impossible, since the clicks go to the CheckBox and Button beneath the item list.
[BugDemo.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/631502/BugDemo.zip)

data.title: Physics behaving differently across platforms depending on FPS
data.body:
OS: X11 & Android
Godot-Version: 2.1.1 official build


If a RigidBody gets tossed up in the air by another RigidBody (in 3D) the linear velocity in y-direction seems to be depending on the FPS the device reaches.
In my example the desktop version is running at a constant 60 FPS while the Android version was tested on a (sort of) low-end device, which is capable of playing the scene at ~40 FPS.
The Desktop version behaves as expected and the object which gets tossed up makes a (little) jump, while in the same scene on Android the object (most of the time) gets tossed up that high, that it leaves the game-platform (3-4 times higher).

If i limit the FPS to 40 with OS.set_target_fps AND limit the physics engine to 40 via fixed_fps in the physics section of the settings, the scene behaves equally on desktop and android.

In my opinion that shouldn't be the case, because (obviously) as a developer i don't know which device a gamer will run the game on. And droppings in the framerate can occur on any device depending on the scene-complexity.

Not shure if this is some sort of bug, but it is not the behaviour i'm expecting.

data.title: Enhanced 3d Navigation Mesh Feature Suggestions.
data.body:
Currently the 3d navigation mesh does not interact with other navigation meshes or collision meshes in any  meaningful way. In coming versions of the engine this may be fixed, but I would like to make sure the concern is at least written down somewhere.

---

Issue:
- All navigation meshes are treated separately. This causes AI to get stuck in a navigation segment.
**How it should be:**
 ![How it should be](http://i.imgur.com/zVEB222.jpg "How it should be")
**[Simulated] How Godot Does It:**
![[Simulated]How Godot Does It](http://i.imgur.com/kg4NKnj.jpg "How Godot Does It")


Example:
- One can get a 3d road asset and connect them end to end. If an AI is placed at the end of the road and tell it to navigate to the other end, it would be unable to. 

Suggestion:
- To solve this I would suggest merging all the navigation meshes, unless it is possible to make pathing cross multiple adjacent or overlapping navigation meshes without connecting them.

---
Issue:
- The navigation mesh generator does not handle obstacles at all. This causes AI to get stuck on objects it should route around.
**How it should Be**
![How it should Be](http://i.imgur.com/2jGD1gk.jpg "How it should Be" )
**[Simulated] How Godot does it.**
![[Simulated]How Godot does it.](http://i.imgur.com/ZqiMLIy.jpg "Simulated]How Godot does it." ) Simulated]

Example:
- If one were to place a a box or chair on the floor and have the navigation mesh generator would not react to the fact that there is an obstacle in contact with the navigation mesh. 

Suggestion:
- My suggestion is that all collision node types should have an option for 'Things that affect the nav mesh' eg: Sofas/cars/buildings and 'Things that do not affect the nav mesh' eg: litter/debris/boxes. The result should be a hole in the nav mesh surrounding the obstacle.

data.title: Make the 3D grid in the editor infinite
data.body:
With 3.0 having a heavy focus on 3D, it will result in a surge of users coming to create 3d games. The 3D grid in the editor is quite small and should be made infinite. I don't know how hard this is to implement but it improves the overall usability of the engine in my opinion.

Thanks.

data.title: Fixed is_window_minimized() and _maximized()
data.body:
Since old version of this function returns if window is minimized/maximized through code, this one returns if it was minimized/maximized by windows title bar icons.

Old code always returns false if minimized/maximized is done by title bar icons

EDIT: it returns if window is minimized/maximized in general (not only by titlebar, just for better understanding)

data.title: Weird alpha cutting in 3D
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux, latest master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I'm experiencing some weird alpha cutting on Sprite3D nodes.

If there are Sprites overlapping on the right side of the viewport, it works like I expect it to work:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8849554/20867513/f9183016-ba46-11e6-9d3b-d1e17714cdf9.png)

If I move the camera so that the Sprites are on the left half of the viewport, it cuts down every pixel which has Alpha < 1. **I don't know it that's intended behavior, but it makes creating a sprite based 2.5D game literally impossible**. But maybe this is changing with the new renderer... :-)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8849554/20867527/53788bb4-ba47-11e6-83d5-8cc82a21552c.png)

All Sprites use this shader:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8849554/20867531/7e57fb58-ba47-11e6-839a-fd284a1e8b17.png)

For example, look at the lower half of the pipe: https://youtu.be/QvAQIWnsLyk

**Steps to reproduce:**
Put some blurred sprites (with alpha) behind each other and look at them from different perspectives.

data.title: Have a way to draw polygon-lines
data.body:
It would be very useful if there was a way in Godot to draw fancy lines.
Using `Node2D.draw_line` is handy for very basic stuff, but doesn't look pretty when tracing a path, has a limited width, and transparency will show artefacts at junction points.

![fancy_lines](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/20867412/9c4bf3e8-ba43-11e6-8115-dee9f24eb86f.png)

Having a fast and efficient way of making line paths would allow, among others:
- Draw better-looking lines in general
- Have a starting point  to implement 2D trails
- Make 2D platforms when textured

Not to mention it would be really faster than writing a GDScript implementation so it becomes more suitable for ingame generation.

data.title: y_sort: make clear which item has to be drawn first when two have the same y-coordinate
data.body:
If you use y_sort and you have the sprites of two entities with the same y-coordinate overlapping horizontally, it is undefined which one has to be drawn first which causes flickering.
This is especially bad when you are using tiles which are larger than the cell size of the grid so they can overlap (which I do a lot).
I added an additional comparation between the x-coordinates to the y-sorter. Not sure if this is wanted in the official build (dont know how much it actually affects performance), but I decided to give it a try.

data.title: BSOD when game is left open for a few minutes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 10 - Godot Version 2.1


**Issue description**:  When leaving my game open for a few minutes, the computer freezes and then gets a Blue Screen of Death. (I am fairly confident that it's not an issue with my computer, because I don't have this issue in any other situation or with any other program). I'm also fairly certain it's not a memory issue, because even if it's just an empty scene, the BSOD happens.


**Steps to reproduce:** Press F5/the "play" button, then wait a minute or so.

data.title: Backport web export changes for 2.1
data.body:
Fixes and simple additions from #7217 and #7219

The window stuff is tricky, so I'm only bringing in the fullscreen functionality, which is pretty straight forward.

For the browser lockup fix, I kept the loading code hardcoded since it's always the same without wasm. 2.1 will also need the additional `.asm.js` file zipped with these changes.

data.title: TextureRegionEditor: Fix mouse wheel scroll speed.
data.body:
Any given mouse wheel input will generate two InputEvents in godot.
The zoom methods here acted on both ones, effectively giving a step value of 4 instead of 2.
Fixes #7236

data.title: Particles2D: Fix initial size randomness property having no effect.
data.body:
It was just a little typo :p
Fixes #7232
